e4: Adopting the new policy aligns with ethical and legal financial reporting standards, mitigating potential litigation risks and enhancing credibility and trust with investors. Keeping the overstatement policy, though adjusted by savvy investors, still invites potential accusations of deception and conflicts with accountability, transparency, and ethical corporate responsibilities.
e5: An ethical reporting policy should prioritize accuracy and transparency, providing investors with truthful representations of financial performance. It should consider equitable stakeholder treatment, incorporating comprehensive disclosures to reduce interpretation burdens or advantage discrepancies. By safeguarding investor trust, it mitigates compliance and reputational risks while maintaining firm integrity and respecting investor rights to owe patrons factual insights.
e6: What strategies specifically would the investor relations team utilize to effectively communicate the change in policy to avoid misconceptions, particularly among retail investors? How will the transition to the new policy address any potential short-term shareholder value impacts, and what forward guidance might stabilize investor confidence following the adjustment?
